Actually, Jane YOU are wrong.  The PhD is approx 3 years of coursework, plus another 2-3 years of clinical training, and dissertation .  THEN we have a post doc requirement.  LCSW's do a fraction of the clinical training and practice that PhD's do while in school. Unlike post-graduation supervision hours, our practicums and internships have required trainings, didactic, assessment batteries, and close supervision.    Plus a lot of training for the LCSW is in SOCIAL WORK -- a chunk of hours earned toward the license can be in client advocacy --  not working with seriously mentally ill patients or therapy.  PhD's are not just more trained in research, we're trained in evidence based practices, have more extensive training and ability to do psychological testing, outcome measures and direct and supervise.  They are certainly not the same degree.

Agreed but some methods seem to work better htan others for certain disorders.  A great deal, but not all, of the improvement does come from "common factors" -- factors common to all methods and are usually contained within the therapeutic relationship itself -- (not WHO the therapist is but the therapists skill at treatment overall)

Mouse - you're right, every individual is complex. What I mean is that in my particular case I don't believe one approach could address all of my needs - CBT is great, but mindfulness and analysis really helped me reach a new level in my treatment that I don't think I could have reached through CBT alone.

I'm not arguing against evidence-based practices. I'm simply saying that the author's suggestion that blending techniques is a negative thing wasn't valid for me, so I can't imagine that it could be valid for everyone. The concept of keeping therapists from employing psychodynamic approaches in practice is frustrating to someone who had such positive results with just that. I'd like to think that others might be able to benefit in the way that I did; regulating the environment in the way that the author's interviewees suggests would keep that from happening.

Replying to the comment posted by Mark from New York.  What is your basis for your conclusion?  Are you aware of the review process for psychology journals in general and the American Psychologist in particular?  The American Psychologist is the most rigorously reviewed journal in the United States.  Reviewers blind to the author's identity are assigned to review the article - months, sometimes years, in advance of publication.  These reviewers are selected because they are expert researchers in their field - in this case psychotherapy research.  I know this particular article when through a number of revisions before the journal editors and reviewers were satisifed with the accuracy of the research and the conclusions drawn.  As individuals, these reviewers and editors are not obliged to agree with the conclusions or theoretical orientation represented in the article - but they are ethically bound to ensure that the research conducted was accurately represented and interpreted. Naturally, being a reputable academic journal, The American Psychologist also later published a critique of Shedler's work by authors of alternative theories.  Just because a critique was published does not mean Shedler's work was invalidated.  What's your source for your conclusion?

The American Psychological Association definition of Evidence-Based Practices in Psychology (EBPP) is the integration of
• the best available research and
• clinical expertise
• in the context of patient characteristics, culture and preferences

This definition recognizes that "softer", harder to measure, individual and relational factors greatly impact therapeutic outcome.

The Heart and Soul of Change, Second Edition: Delivering What Works in Therapy
http://www.apa.org/pubs/books/4317206.aspx
is a key work in summarizing where we are so far in figuring out how to be as effective therapists as possible;

"The second edition of The Heart and Soul of Change also demonstrates the power of systematic client feedback to improve effectiveness and efficiency and legitimize psychotherapy services to third party payers. In this way, psychotherapy is implemented one person at a time, based on that unique individual's perceptions of the progress and fit of the therapy and therapist." - APA website

Our book, Treatment Planning for Children with Autism Spectrum Disorders: An Individualized, Problem-Solving Approach (Wiley, 2012) tackles this issue with regards to treatments for children with Autism.

Would that helping complicated people facing complicated challenges were as simple as following a formula.

Karen Levine, Ph.D.

"As for patients asking about outcomes, I usually acknowledge their anxiety about entering into this new strange alliance and suggest that they are the experts about who can best help them."

Wow, what a remarkably condescending avoidance tactic!!
It's precisely this type of behavior that discredits therapy and makes the need for standards in the field all the more pressing.

First of all, evidence based treatments do not operate the way community based treatments must. In the community, one cannot turn away patients because they do not fit into your protocol, one cannot purge patients who do not follow protocol, one cannot randomly assign patients to therapists, patients can request transfers for any reason or no reason at all, and one does not offer free treatments to those who do fit into the protocol.

In the real world of treatment, patients often don't tell you what the big trauma is until they trust you and feel safe. That can take months. More than 16 weeks anyway.

As for patients asking about outcomes, I usually acknowledge their anxiety about entering into this new strange alliance and suggest that they are the experts about who can best help them. There are many people who have felt helped by their sessions with me, but that is all garbage if this patient does not feel I understand them and appreciate their struggles.

“A lot of students come in and say, ‘I hate science, but I’m good with people. I like to listen and help them,’ ” said Dr. Becker.

At the undergraduate level, I've had MANY students say that they are bad at math and writing, so they want to major in psychology.

It is not infrequent that the comments, as in this "case", are far more knowledgable and informative, not to mention interesting, than the  column or article that precipitated them. As for CBT-- I don't have to be a scientist to know that when something sounds too good to be true, it usually is.

Most studies of CBT indicate at best a 70% success rate. And I claim much of that is fraudulent. I myself was generating fraudulent behavior for a study last fall and continued to generate fraudulent behavior as recently as this spring. (The researchers wanted to see if a radical cognitive shift could cure pervasive depression. In fact it made it much, much worse.)

I've given up hope for psychology as a legitimate science.

Yes but antibiotics consistently generate near 100% success rates. CBT (like all psycho-therapies), generate at best 70% success rates. Placebo studies generate around 30% success rates.

Comparisons of psycho-therapies to antibiotics is something of a legerdemain used to imply that they are just as effective when in fact they are not.

The hallmark of successful treatments is the near eradication of the problem at hand. (Witness the relative dearth of infectious deaths.) Yet despondency and depression continue to be pervasive phenomena. True cures become widely adopted across all cultures because they actually work.

Evangelicals are united in their support of Republican ideals in general *because* they agree on social issues. It's simply intellectually easier (and politically expedient) to agree on other issues - when the stuff you consider to be of (after)life or death importance is at stake.

Gently now. It's not that straightforward. Yes, providers are cautious about being evaluated, but there are some good reasons for that. The field is in early stages of developing empirical methods for evaluating provider effectiveness. It's moving slowly, but it's still moving in the right direction.

1) As a field, we're still in the early stages of evaluating how best to measure change during psychotherapy. Our measures are self-report, and contain a fair amount of error and user-bias.

2) Some clinicians take on case loads with different levels of severity. Should those who take on more difficult patients be held to the same standard as those with more straightforward cases? Of course not. However, the field is still in early stages of adopting methods that account for differences in case load.

3) We ARE starting to evaluate clinicians. For a great summary of many of the tools developed for doing so, look to Michael Barkham, Gillian Hardy, and John Mellor-Clark's book Developing and Delivering Practice-Based Evidence: A Guide for the Psychological Therapies. They cover many of the repeated-measure tools currently being used in daily practice.

Look to work on Therapist-Effects by Paul Crits-Christoph, Bruce Wampold and David Kraus for examples of research examining the impact of the person of the therapist on treatment outcomes. The work is being done, and the field will change over time. It's important that there be skeptics, who hold the research to a high standard.

The fact that almost none of the self-reported therapists on this site are discussing the issues around treatment failures and trying to seek solutions or standards to address and minimize the potential harm they inflict, and instead are trying so hard to defend their current status quo practices, speaks to the character of those in the field, and thus the disappointing state of the field.

Anne, the PhD in psychology may take 5 - 7 years, but the concepts involved are absolutely trivial. (I mean let's face it - the 'everything is perspective' CBT approach is basically bartender advice.) The little math that is required is basically watered down statistics of the ANOVA and Regression type.

MDs on the other hand (of which I am not, btw) need to learn chemistry, physics, biology, and other much more demanding subject matter.

To compare psychology to actual medicine is to compare horses with automobiles.

Eric,
I am talking about Phoenix where my wife's grandmother lived. We still have a couple of friends there. I go to Death Valley in February, actually Shoshone, but close enough. As for anything east of the Mississippi, I see no sense in living in a steam bath.

I worked hard all my life to be able to have a decent life style here. We are opera fans, among other entertainments. If I want more pop style I can go to Tahoe or Reno, just a couple of hours away.

And I have been exposed to the "riff raff, in the low cost states, I even got to spend a few months in Biloxi. I really enjoyed NYC, the USO gave us tickets to Broadway plays and musicals, the Met, the Symphony, and at the time the big museums were free, I got to hear some of the great jazz bands as I did in New Orleans. My best friend was from Brooklyn but I would not want to live there.

The desert gets hot, but there are thousands of miles of ORV routes if you go there. It cools down in the evening, and you can actually see the stars.

I have ridden bicycle from Tucson to Sierra Vista over Sonoita Pass and through Ft. Huachuca, they did loops through Bisbee and Tombstone, and down to Patagonia. but we did those trips in March. Sierra Vista's altitude makes it a bit cooler. I have hiked the Kibab and the Tonto Trail, been to the Desert Museum. Tucson is a nice town but a bit limited. Great air museum but Phoenix, Surprise, and that area is the dumps.
Linda, it must be like parts of Florida. In any case, I doubt Dave would want to associate with any of us red necked goobers from either state.

Well Eric, I do have a graduate degree specializing in sensation and perception. I have a pretty good library with quite a bit of California history in it, and my wife also has a degree in business, so our acquaintances are mostly educated to some degree or other.

If by redneck you mean your time is spent sitting around the barbeque talking about how any beers you drank last night, or the great babes you saw down at the local pub, so be it. For ourselves we like to discuss adventures we have had or are contemplating, such as we are working on planning a trip to Iquazu Falls in Brazil soon and some of our friends have been there so we prefer to hear about such things. We have been to the Louvre, Versallis, Beijing, and Shanghai, among other places. I have been to Florida and really do not care that much for Plametto bugs.

If you want to make fun of our cultural pursuits fine, we will not meet at a cafe in Vienna anyway. Yes we have a good life style and I pay more taxes than I would like, but you get what you pay for.

Well I am going to have a big tax bill this year, thanks to some capital gains, but I am not going to move to someplace where it gets to 118 in the shade and stays in the high nineties all night, just to save a few bucks.

I do not have to buy special winter clothing, and the gas and electric bills do not change much from summer to winter, although the AC does raise the electricity a bit. I can drive to Reno in two hours and SF in one and a half, I can go to the SF Opera instead of a western joint.

I have been to some of those low cost states, and if that is the lifestyle you like, please leave. Prices and wages are relative where ever you go. Sure it is cheaper to live in Kansas, or South Dakota, but you freeze your butt off half the year.

The ocean is just down the road a few miles, and the skiing is just up the road a few miles. There are salmon and steelhead in the American river just down the street, many local farms where fresh vegetables are sold at good prices, several gold rush towns whith good restaurants, and a swimming pool in my back yard.

I can ride a bike along the American River from Sacramento to Folsom Lake, get Satsuma Mandarins just up the road, and we bought 20 lbs of Fuji apples for $14 at apple hill.

Life style is far more important to me, than a few dollars I could save moving to some place where the biggest event is the Fourth of July parade.
